content.webTitle: Morning Mail: Australians in combat in Iraq, Hong Kong, Rabbitohs NRL grand final win

fields.headline: Morning Mail: Australians in combat in Iraq, Hong Kong, Rabbitohs NRL grand final win
fields.bodyText: Good morning folks, and welcome to the Morning Mail – sign up here to get it straight to your inbox before 8am every weekday. Iraq Chief of Defence Mark Binskin has confirmed the first Australian armed combat mission against Isis in Iraq was conducted overnight. Syrian Kurd officials say air strikes aren’t working, as Isis fighters continued undeterred to the edge of the besieged town of Kobani, where fleeing refugees have told of torture, mutilation and rape at the hands of Islamic State militants. British Muslims have expressed fury and anguish in the wake of the brutal killing of hostage Alan Henning, while the former chief of the UK armed forces says “western boots on the ground” in Iraq is the only way to defeat Isis. Finance minister Mathias Cormann says he’s ‘not ruling out’ raising taxes to pay for Australia’s involvement in Iraq. A Galaxy poll found Australians back air strikes against Isis in Iraq by three to one. Australian news and politics • South Sydney Rabbitohs end 43 years of hurt to win the NRL grand final 30-6 against the Canterbury Bulldogs. • Asio welcomes proposed national security laws that will see it gain broaderpowers to secretly detain Australians without charge and conduct “coercive questioning”. • Speculation is mounting that Campbell Newman will move into an ultra safe conservative seat for the Queensland election after the LNP blocked from standing for the seat he’s held for 10 years. • EXCLUSIVE: minutes of meetings and an intelligence report obtained by Guardian Australia reveal staff at Nauru detention centres have reported persistent acts of child abuse and self harm within the offshore camps over several months. Around the world • Thousands of protesters in Hong Kong remained gathered around government offices as the deadline for them to move on passed at midnight. • Mass grave found in Mexican town where 43 students went missing last weekend. • Cuban migrants on board a homemade boat ‘drank blood to survive’ three weeks adrift in Caribbean before being rescued by fishermen, but less than half of them survived. More from around the web • Among the most read on the Guardian this morning: F1 driver Jules Bianchi suffered a severe head injury after a crash in the Japanese Grand Prix. Bianchi has since undergone brain surgery. • Australia’s spending burden threatens to tip the nation into decades of deficits, according to new government findings, reports The Australian. • A Brisbane chef who was discovered cooking parts of his girlfriend’s dismembered body seemed “happy” and “normal” days before the killing, The Courier-Mail reports. • Destructive 100km/h winds and extreme fire danger conditions are expected to hit South Australia, prompting a total fire ban, the Adelaide Advertiser reports. One last thing The mystery over the location of Ned Kelly’s skull remains unsolved. Turns out the one kept inside a Tupperware container for years isn’t his. Have an excellent day – and if you spot anything I’ve missed, let me know in the comments here or on Twitter @earleyedition. Sign up Get the Morning Mail direct to your inbox before 8am every day by signing up here.
